properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-20T06:25:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-19T14:25:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2519327794.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls possible beginning this afternoon into tonight. With the arrival of cold northwesterly winds, snow squalls are forecast to develop over Lake Huron and Georgian Bay this afternoon. As winds shift later this afternoon, these snow squalls are expected to move over the area and then continue into tonight. Local snowfall amounts in the 10 to 15 cm range will be possible by Thursday morning. An additional 2 to 4 cm will be possible Thursday as the squalls weaken. Visibilities will likely be reduced at times in heavy snow and blowing snow, particularly over exposed areas. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-20T10:59:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-19T19:00:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1640390062.2020
Area: Midland - Coldwater - Orr Lake, Orillia - Lagoon City - Washago, Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, rain, and strong southerly winds expected today. Total snowfall amounts: 5 to 10 cm. Total rainfall amounts: 5 to 10 mm, except up to 15 mm along the southern shore. Maximum wind gusts: southerly generally between 60 to 80 km/h except 100 along parts of the coast. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Strong southerly winds will accompany the snow causing a few hours of poor visibilities in snow and blowing snow over all areas near noon. The snow will change through ice pellets to rain early in the afternoon over all areas. The rain and mild temperatures are likely to cause localized flooding and water pooling on roads. The public should prepare for poor travel conditions throughout the day today. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-20T04:59:51-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values close to minus 40 expected tonight and Thursday morning. Under clear skies and moderate winds temperatures are forecast to reach near minus 30 degrees celsius tonight and Thursday morning with wind chill values close to minus 40. Temperatures are expected to rise by midday Thursday bringing an end to the extreme cold. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-20T08:20:28-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Winds are expected to increase at Coral Harbour through the overnight hours. These winds combined with very cold temperatures approaching -40 will give wind chill values near -55 through the overnight and morning hours. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Another frontal system will move across the Haines and Skagway roads on Thursday morning bringing additional snow and southerly winds. The strong winds will create blowing snow giving reduced visibilities. Conditions will improve Thursday evening as the system moves eastward. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. High concentrations of pollutants are expected to persist into this morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-20T20:39:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-02-20T04:41:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2784912339.2020
Area: La Sarre area, Amos area, Lebel-sur-Quévillon area, Senneterre area, Rouyn area, Malartic area, Val d'Or - Louvicourt area

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A developing low pressure system over the Arctic mainland coast has brought strong gusty easterly winds and blizzard conditions to Ulukhaktok. The winds will ease late Thursday morning and blizzard conditions should end near noon. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. February 19, 2020: The Ministry of Environment & Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Interior Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Castlegar due to high concentrations of dust that are expected to persist for the next 24 hours. This advisory will be updated tomorrow. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have underlying medical conditions such as breathing or lung conditions, hay fever, asthma or persons who react strongly to dust. If you are experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheeze, follow the advice of your health care provider. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-20T16:35:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-02-20T00:36:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3072335643.2020

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Dangerous wind chills of -50 to -55 will develop in Iqaluit tonight as temperatures dip to a low near -36C and northwest winds strengthen to 30 km/h. Warning level wind chills will end on Thursday morning as temperatures climb towards -30C, but northwest winds of 40 gusting 60 km/h will maintain wind chills of -45 to -50 through the day. Dangerous wind chills below -50 will likely redevelop on Thursday evening as temperatures begin to fall again. Cold conditions will continue through the weekend with wind chills generally in the -40 to -50 range. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Summary:

Maximum wind gusts: southerly 60 to 80 km/h today and westerly 70 km/h overnight tonight and Thursday. Locations: western Newfoundland.
